reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because this word gets stuck onto other things to describe tribes and groups.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Go look at the next lesson, now.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading of the kanji is same as for 並ぶ, so if you know that you can figure out the reading for this one as well.

The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this:

The <vocabulary>owner</vocabulary> of those <reading>nu</reading>de <reading>shee</reading>p (ぬし) doesn’t even need their wool, he just likes owning nude sheep. So he keeps them as pets and shaves them every day. He’s not interested in sheep with fur. Only nude sheep for this owner!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are <vocabulary>scarce</vocabulary>, you have <reading>to bo</reading>at (とぼ) all the way across the lake to find any resources or food, as your side of the lake is picked dry.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the words 先 and 程, put together.
<vocabulary>To chill something</vocabulary>, you need to apply cold, not <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ).

The reading is 切る cut short to きっ, then ふ rendaku'd to ぷ. It's a bit of a troublesome word, so concentrate on this now a bit so you can get it in the reviews.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to こっ, though, so look out for that.
The reading comes from 埋める.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 太陽.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 官僚 will help a lot too.

You want <vocabulary>to move something close to</vocabulary> you, but it's out of reach. The solution, of course, is to take out your trusty <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ) and lasso that thing and pull it closer!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 幼稚 as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Do you mind if I go <vocabulary>to prolong</vocabulary> things? The answer? "<reading>No</reading> (の), I don't mind."

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But 強  has two on'yomi readings, and you haven't really seen this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Think about how when you commit a <vocabulary>robbery</vocabulary>, you <reading>go</reading> (ごう) into someone's house, then you go to jail as well, if you're caught.

You should speak in a <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>faint</vocabulary> voice when you <reading>cuss</reading> (かす). So delicate that the cuss words are <vocabulary>indistinct</vocabulary> to other people, even. It's the only acceptable way to cuss.

This word's reading is pretty weird. We're going to think back to a couple different words to put this one together. The word for heart (心), is こころ. The word for good is よい (or いい, but for this word's sake, よい). A "good heart (feeling)" is one where your heart feels nice and warm and fuzzy (figuratively, not literally. If it's literal, go to the hospital please). That is a <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary> feeling. A こころよい feeling.

The reading comes from 怖い.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Do you remember doing that? Oh man, those were the days. How 懐かしい.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. The reading for 成 is from 成る and it keeps the る part. It's just hidden in the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll know this reading!

You haven't learned this reading for 我 so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Let us present you with <vocabulary>our</vocabulary> <reading>wa</reading>lrus (わ). Well it's <vocabulary>my</vocabulary> walrus really, but I'm happy to share.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so hopefully you can read this on your own.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know this, so you're all good here!

<vocabulary>To take a picture</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to take a video</vocabulary>… You "take" all these things. And how do you say "to take" in Japanese? It's <reading>取る</reading> (とる), which happens to share a reading with this word. Different kanji but related meanings, and exactly the same reading!

The one with the <vocabulary>flag</vocabulary> is the Mad <reading>Hatter</reading> (はた). Just imagine looking through a group of people. You have to find the Mad Hatter, and he has to find you. That's why he offered to wear a flag on his hat.

The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. 浮 takes the kun'yomi うき (from 浮く), 世 also takes the kun'yomi よ, and then 絵 takes the on'yomi え. Put that all together and you have うきよえ! Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!
This kanji uses the kun'yomi read for the first kanji, and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go grab a cup of water so you don't become dehydrated, okay?

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Causing you <vocabulary>to leak</vocabulary> all over the floor (we're talking blood, here) is your friend <reading>Moe</reading> (も). If you know someone named Moe, imagine them doing this. If you don't, think of a famous Moe.

The reading can be the on'yomi for 年 or the kun'yomi. So, you can do either よくねん or よくとし, or preferably both.

The reading can be what you've learned with the kanji, よくあさ, or it can be the on'yomi reading across the board, よくちょう. Both are good to remember because よくちょう is more formal (you'll use that reading in writing more often) and よくあさ is more informal - you'll use that in speaking more often.

Where you're from, everyone measures their <vocabulary>height</vocabulary> in <reading>ce</reading>lery (せ). No inches or centimeters for you, it's celery sticks only. How many celery sticks tall are you?

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know both of these readings, but in case you need a reminder, here's a mnemonic to help you out:

You really like <vocabulary>tonkotsu ramen</vocabulary> so you just ate a whole <reading>ton</reading> (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of <vocabulary>pork bone ramen</vocabulary>.

You know the word 先ず (まず)? It means something along the lines of "first of all." So, if you're <vocabulary>poor</vocabulary>, <reading>first of all</reading> (まず), you're going to want to get some help. Second of all, learn how to play the guitar and make funny jokes.

The on'yomi for 読 (どく) is the same as the reading in 読者. In case you forgot, think about how you just got a subscription to <reading>dock</reading> (どく) magazine. It's all about docks and dock related things. How exciting.

The reading is on'yomi, which is great for 購 but not as great for 買. Luckily, the reading for 買 is <reading>buy</reading> (ばい), which is the same as the meaning, which is a pretty awesome coincidence.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>To go beyond</vocabulary> <reading>child</reading> (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in both the USA and Japan.

Remember the re-zoner? Well, <vocabulary>to repel</vocabulary> bad luck, <reading>she, re-zo</reading>ned (しりぞ) the whole place. No bad luck allowed inside the zone.
The reading comes from 逆らう and 様, put together. A bit of an <vocabulary>upside down</vocabulary> reading if I do say so myself, but you do what you gotta do.

You want <vocabulary>to play</vocabulary> with everyone, but every once in a while someone doesn't want to play with you. You know what? That's okay. If someone doesn't want to play with you, they're the <reading>a**hole</reading> (あそ), not you.

In terms of places where you want <vocabulary>to deposit</vocabulary> your money, the last place on your list should be <reading>a zoo</reading> (あず). I mean seriously, you know the animals are just gonna munch up all your dolla bills.

You should just do it, just be<reading>cause</reading>.

You're always going <vocabulary>to make noise</vocabulary> and be boisterous when you eat something <reading>sour</reading> (さわ). Imagine stuffing lemon slices, sour candy, and umeboshi into your mouth. All at once. See how much noise you make? They're so sour, and they make you so boisterous.
